This made him nervous. What if that dog attacked someone? Jose Luis didn't know that people could bring pets with them onto trains. It seemed unsafe. He stepped closer to the dog. The German Shepard seemed friendly enough. Just as he put out his hand to pet the dog

column1: Please don't pet him. He's working
column2: the lady told him. Jose Luis didn't understand. The woman explained that she was blind and that the dog Hampton acted as her eyes
column3: helping her navigate her way around the city. The woman pointed out the special vest that Hampton was wearing. The vest was printed with the words ""service animal"".

column1: Jose Luis had never heard of service animals before. ""Service animals like Hampton are allowed into public places that most pets are not. Hampton is more than a pet. He helps me be self-sufficient and do the things that I need to do in the city
column2: the woman explained. The woman also told Jose Luis that service animals had to go through special training so that they learn how to behave in public places and do not get distracted. ""People need to help too though
column3: by not petting him

column1: The woman continued to explain that service animals do not just help the blind. Some animals act as therapy animals. Therapy animals go into hospitals and nursing homes. These animals lower the stress levels of people who are very sick or who have just had operations. They also encourage people to recover. Therapy animals are especially popular in children's hospitals. Dogs really can be man's best friends."¬¬~2¬Que clasificacion segun CEFR le darias a este texto¬¬A1

column6: C2¬Si~3¬Observaciones y sugerencias¬¬¬No~0¬Texto 3 de 6¬"It was Saturday morning. Mary walked out of her house with twenty dollars in her pocket and a spirit full of optimism. She had spent the previous night in front of her television set watching a reality show that followed lucky people who had found amazing things at their local thrift shops. All of these people had bought seemingly ordinary items for extremely low prices
column7: and ended up discovering that their items were actually very valuable treasures. After having spent five consecutive hours watching other people's experiences
column8: Mary was determined to give bargain hunting a try in hopes of finding something that would make her rich.

column1: One of her favorite stories from the show was of a man who had purchased a copy of the Declaration of Independence thinking that it was a cheap replica
column2: for only $2. He ended up discovering that the print was actually one of only 200 official copies of the Declaration of Independence commissioned by John Quincy Adams in 1820. The man ended up making $477
column3: 650 after selling it.

column1: As Mary walked into her local thrift shop
column2: she tried recalling what all the people in the reality show had looked for. The most common items that people got rich from were paintings and so she headed straight to the Home Decorations aisle. Once there
column3: she couldn't decide which looked most expensive. They actually all seemed pretty ugly to her. ""Excuse me
column4: Mary said to an elderly woman walking by. ""Which painting do you think could make me richer?"" Confused
column5: the old lady quickly pointed at one and walked away.

column1: The painting the old lady had pointed at was of a cat collage with almost 20 different cat faces jumbled atop of one another. ""Definitely not my first choice
column2: thought Mary. However
column3: she trusted destiny's decision and bought the painting for five dollars. After putting it up online
column4: she began receiving dozens of emails asking if the picture frame displayed came with the painting. In order to see what all the buzz about the frame was about
column5: she took it to an antique store and asked if there was anything special about the frame. ""Of course
column6: it is special!"" remarked the clerk at the store. ""Its wood and age make it at least $25
column7: 000!"" Mary ended up selling the frame for $30
column9: the buyer returned the ugly painting to her through the mail."¬¬~2¬Que clasificacion segun CEFR le darias a este texto¬¬A1
column14: C2¬Si~3¬Observaciones y sugerencias¬¬¬No~0¬Texto 4 de 6¬﻿The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has appealed to Washington to sort out its finances after the US pulled back from the brink of a debt default and hundreds of thousands of federal employees returned to work after a 16-day government shutdown.

column1: As the US President
column2: Barack Obama
column3: warned “We’ve got to get out of the habit of governing by crisis

column1: “It will be essential to reduce uncertainty surrounding the conduct of fiscal policy by raising the debt limit in a more durable manner
column2: ” she said.

column1: “We also continue to encourage the US to approve a budget for 2014 and replace the sequester with gradually phased-in measures that would not harm the recovery
column2: and to adopt a balanced and comprehensive medium-term fiscal plan.”

column1: A Senate-drafted peace deal that contained almost no concessions to the conservatives who had driven the country to the precipice of a new financial crisis was passed by the Republican-dominated House of Representatives just hours before a deadline to extend the US debt limit was to pass.
The World Bank
column2: too
column3: expressed its relief that the global economy had “dodged a potential catastrophe ”
column6: urging policymakers in all countries to “continue to focus on crafting and implementing policies that promote economic growth and boost jobs and opportunity for all ”.

column1: Stock markets in Japan
column2: China
column3: Hong Kong and South Korea initially reflected relief after the Republicans finally capitulated in their failed attempt to undermine Obama’s healthcare reforms. But
column5: stock markets overall displayed a muted reaction
column6: with traders apparently expecting another battle in Washington early in 2014.

column1: The shutdown is estimated to have cost the US $24bn
column2: according to the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s. China’s official Xinhua News Agency had accused Washington of jeopardizing other countries’ dollar assets. China is the US government’s largest creditor.

column1: Obama signed the necessary legislation to fend off a default shortly after midnight on Thursday after a Republican split in the House of Representatives. The bill had passed easily with broad bipartisan support in the Senate
column2: where Democratic and Republican leaders forged the agreement. It offers a temporary fix
column3: funding the government until 15 January and raising the debt ceiling until 7 February.

column1: But the president made clear he did not expect another bitter budget fight and shutdown in 2014.
In brief remarks at the White House shortly before the House vote
column2: Obama said he hoped the deal would “lift the cloud of uncertainty” that had hung over the country in recent weeks.

column1: “Once this agreement arrives on my desk
column2: I will sign it immediately
column3: ” he said
column4: in a statement delivered at the White House. “Hopefully
column5: next time it won’t be in the eleventh hour. We’ve got to get out of the habit of governing by crisis.”

column1: As he left the lectern after his Wednesday night press briefing
column2: the president was asked by a journalist whether the crisis would happen all over again in a few months. Speaking over his shoulder
column3: Obama replied

column1: Earlier
column2: the Republican senator Mike Lee had struck a defiant tone
column3: perhaps indicating more trouble ahead: “The media keeps asking: 'Was it worth it?' My answer is
column4: it is always worth it to do the right thing.” He added: “This is not over.”

column1: However
column2: the political deal was one of the worst of all possible outcomes for Republicans. None of their stated goals was achieved and polls showed that voters overwhelmingly blamed them for the crisis.
